conclusion: Two cars, A and B, are driving on a straight road and brake at the same time due to a siren warning about an accident ahead. They collide, and we need to determine if the collision happened before or after 20 seconds of braking.
The velocity-time graph shows car A starting at 25 m/s and car B at 15 m/s, both decreasing linearly to zero over time.
The x-axis of the graph is time in seconds, and the y-axis is velocity in meters per second.

premise: Car A starts at 25 m/s and reaches 0 m/s at around 30 seconds.
conclusion: The deceleration of car A, a_A, is -25/30 m/s² ≈ -0.833 m/s².

premise: Car B starts at 15 m/s and reaches 0 m/s at around 25 seconds.
conclusion: The deceleration of car B, a_B, is -15/25 m/s² = -0.6 m/s².
Collision occurs when the distance traveled by car A equals the distance traveled by car B plus the initial distance between them.
At 20 seconds, both lines on the graph intersect, meaning both cars have the same velocity at that time.

premise: Initial velocity of A: v_A0 = 25 m/s, Initial velocity of B: v_B0 = 15 m/s, Deceleration of A: a_A = -0.833 m/s², Deceleration of B: a_B = -0.6 m/s².
conclusion: The distance traveled by car A after time t is s_A = 25t - 0.4165t².

premise: Initial velocity of B: v_B0 = 15 m/s, Deceleration of B: a_B = -0.6 m/s².
conclusion: The distance traveled by car B after time t is s_B = 15t - 0.3t².

premise: s_A = s_B for collision, meaning car A has caught up with car B.

conclusion: Factor t: t(10 - 0.1165t) = 0, so t = 0 or t ≈ 85.88 seconds.

premise: Car A stops at 30 seconds, and car B stops at 25 seconds.
conclusion: The collision between the two cars must have occurred at some point within the 20 seconds after they started braking.
